DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Higher
Eds: An AMer expected by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended higher Tuesday against major foreign currencies in light trading in Europe. Gold prices also rose. The dollar got a lift early in the day on speculation that the Bank of Japan will soon raise its key interest rate, now standing at 3.75 percent. Those rumors, which were denied by Japanese authorities, and profit-taking in the West German mark combined to lift the dollar, market watchers said. The rumors of a Japanese rate hike helped rekindle sentiment that an interest-rate rise will eventually be needed to shore up the yen. But dealers said trading was calm. ``Let's face it, there's been no terrific drama today,'' said one senior dealer. ``Trading has been extremely narrow with virtually no range at all.'' In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.42 Japanese yen to close at 143.80 yen. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 143.80 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6005 from $1.6020 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.7365 West German marks, up from 1.7245; 1.5615 Swiss francs, up from 1.5480; 5.9300 French francs, up from 5.8890; 1.9575 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9455; 1,291.25 Italian lire, up from 1,289.25; and 1.1613 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1610. Gold prices rose in London to a late bid of $413.75 a troy ounce from $409.25 late Monday and to $414.00 in Zurich from $408.50 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.83 to $412.80 an ounce. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $5.57 a troy ounce from $5.55 late Monday.
